    Zeta Function Connections: Ihara, M√∂bius, and Chromatic

    Status: Documentation Complete Seed: 1069 Key Insight: Non-backtracking walks ‚ÜîÔ∏é Ihara zeta ‚ÜîÔ∏é Ramanujan graphs

    Overview

    The 3-MATCH gadget connects to deep mathematics through three zeta functions:

    1. Ihara Zeta Function - Counts non-backtracking closed walks
    2. M√∂bius Function - Filters prime (non-backtracking) paths
    3. Chromatic Polynomial - Counts proper colorings via M√∂bius inversion

    1. Ihara Zeta Function

    Definition

    For a graph G, the Ihara zeta function is:

    Œ∂_G(u) = ‚àè_{[C]} (1 - u^{|C|})^{-1}

    where the product is over equivalence classes of primitive closed non-backtracking walks.

    Connection to Non-Backtracking Matrix

    Œ∂_G(u)^{-1} = (1 - u¬≤)^{|E| - |V|} det(I - uB)

    where B is the non-backtracking matrix indexed by directed edges.

    Our Implementation

    # lib/three_match_geodesic_gadget.rb
class NonBacktrackingGeodesic
  # Generate geodesic: never revisit a state
  # This is equivalent to prime paths (Œº(n) ‚â† 0)
  def generate!
    @length.times do |i|
      # Filter to non-visited (non-backtracking)
      valid = candidates.reject { |c| @visited.include?(c[:hex]) }
      # ...
    end
  end
end

    2. Ramanujan Graphs and Spectral Gap

    Ramanujan Property

    A d-regular graph is Ramanujan if:

    Œª ‚â§ 2‚àö(d-1)

    where Œª is the largest non-trivial eigenvalue.

    Key Result (Bordenave, Lelarge, Massouli√© 2015)

    ‚ÄúThe non-backtracking matrix has appeared in connection with the Ihara zeta function and in some generalizations of Ramanujan graphs.‚Äù

    Spectral Redemption Conjecture (Confirmed): Community detection succeeds above the feasibility threshold using non-backtracking eigenvectors.

    Our Spectral Gap

    For the ternary random walk on trits {-1, 0, +1}:

    Spectral gap = 1/4
Mixing time = 4 steps

    File: lean4/MusicTopos/SpectralGap.lean

    3. M√∂bius Function and Prime Paths

    Classical M√∂bius Function

    Œº(n) = { 1      if n = 1
       { (-1)^k if n = p‚ÇÅp‚ÇÇ...p‚Çñ (k distinct primes)
       { 0      if n has squared prime factor

    Key Values for Our System

    n Œº(n) Meaning
    1 1 Identity
    2 -1 Prime (single factor)
    3 -1 Prime - key for tritwise inversion
    4 0 Squared (2¬≤) - backtracking
    5 -1 Prime
    6 1 Two primes (2¬∑3)

    M√∂bius Inversion

    If f(n) = Œ£_{d|n} g(d) then:

    g(n) = Œ£_{d|n} Œº(n/d) f(d)

    Application to Non-Backtracking

    Theorem: A path of length n is non-backtracking (prime) iff Œº(n) ‚â† 0.

    # lib/three_match_geodesic_gadget.rb
class BackAndForthFilter
  def forward(sequence)
    sequence.each_with_index.map do |item, i|
      n = i + 1
      mu = Moebius.mu(n)
      case mu
      when 0 then { filtered: true }   # Composite (backtracking)
      else { filtered: false, mu: mu } # Prime (kept)
      end
    end
  end
end

    4. Chromatic Polynomial and Bond Lattice

    Chromatic Polynomial P(G, k)

    The number of proper k-colorings of graph G is given by:

    P(G, k) = Œ£_{œÄ ‚àà L(G)} Œº(œÄ, 1ÃÇ) ¬∑ k^{|œÄ|}

    where L(G) is the bond lattice of G and Œº is the M√∂bius function on posets.

    Reference (CioabƒÉ & Murty)

    ‚ÄúAugust Ferdinand M√∂bius introduced the function which bears his name in 1831‚Ä¶ The M√∂bius function is a very important tool not only in combinatorics, but also in algebra and number theory.‚Äù

    Connection to 3-Coloring

    For 3-coloring (our system):

    P(G, 3) = number of valid 3-colorings

    Our 3-MATCH gadget enforces local constraints such that: - Valid 3-MATCH at each clause ‚Üí Valid 3-coloring globally

    5. Zeta Polynomial (Crapo)

    Zeta Polynomial of a Poset

    Z(P, n) = |{chains x‚ÇÄ < x‚ÇÅ < ... < x_n in P}|

    Relationship to M√∂bius

    The zeta polynomial and M√∂bius function are connected by:

    Œ£_{k=0}^n Œº_k ¬∑ Z(P, n-k) = [n = 0]

    This gives chain generalizations of M√∂bius identities.

    6. The Tritwise Triangle

    Our system unifies three perspectives:

            Ihara Zeta (Graphs)
              /\
             /  \
            /    \
           /      \
    M√∂bius -------- Chromatic
  (Number Theory)   (Combinatorics)

    Connections:

    1. Ihara ‚ÜîÔ∏é M√∂bius: Non-backtracking paths have Œº ‚â† 0
    2. M√∂bius ‚ÜîÔ∏é Chromatic: Inversion gives chromatic polynomial
    3. Chromatic ‚ÜîÔ∏é Ihara: k-colorings relate to zeta poles

    9. Commands

    # Run M√∂bius demo
ruby -I lib -r moebius -e "Moebius.demo"

ruby lib/three_match_geodesic_gadget.rb

# Test Ihara connection (via back-and-forth filter)
just three-match

# Build Lean4 proofs
cd lean4 && lake build

    10. The Unworld Connection

    The zeta functions connect to unworld (replacing time with derivation):

    1. Ihara zeta counts paths without backtracking (no revisiting)
    2. Seed chaining creates non-backtracking derivation sequences
    3. Spectral gap ensures mixing after finite derivations
    Time ‚Üí Derivation ‚Üí Zeta ‚Üí Proof

    Summary: The Ihara zeta function, M√∂bius inversion, and chromatic polynomial form a unified framework for understanding our 3-MATCH gadget. Non-backtracking walks are prime paths (Œº ‚â† 0), which connect to the spectral gap of Ramanujan graphs and the proper colorings counted by chromatic polynomials.
